data.text: Shimano Deore Hubs on Ryde Andra Wheels

Hey ! I'm looking for a good pair of wheels for touring. After some research I think Ryde andra 30 26" 36H are the best rims for me and now I have a question about the hubs. I found these hubs Shimano Deore HB-T610 and Shimano Deore FH-T610 . Do you use any of these hubs or ryde andra rim or can you help me with any advice ? Thanks and happy cycling !
I have the same plan.. i only have to decide for the spokes.. maybe sapim strong?
data.author: Nejƒçi Zlobko

data.text: Shimano Deore components are fantastic, the hubs pictured are rim brake only, you can get a disc brake version and fit rim brake rims ü§î
data.author: Martin Malloy

data.text: I have deore hubs on my hybrid. They are excellent. Smooth and quiet. The freehub is silent compared to my other wheels.
data.author: Nathan Turnage

data.text: Yes...use Deore rear on Ryde Andra 40.. it's a e bike rim..26"..easy to service..use son dynamo hub on Andra 30 rim at front.Use the recommend pads if your using v brakes...Swiss stop blue I think Happy travels üëçüè¥Û†ÅßÛ†Å¢Û†Å∑Û†Å¨Û†Å≥Û†Åø
data.author: Paul Williams

data.text: The Swiss Stop Blue pads are specifically for the Supersonic ceramic coated Andra rims. For the non-coated versions regular Kool Stop Salmon are probably the best. Kool Stop also makes a version of the Swiss Stop Blue pads--the Kool Stop versions are black, work just as well and squeal a bit less.
data.author: M Sebastian Richard Williams

data.text: I'm sponsored by them so I fit what they give me ..I'm full time so carry few sets...rims last about 2 years 40,000 miles üëçüè¥Û†ÅßÛ†Å¢Û†Å∑Û†Å¨Û†Å≥Û†Åø
data.author: Paul Williams

data.text: I have Andra 40 with Cool Stop break pads and after 6000km I can already feel the wear on the rims. I think these kind of special pads just eat away the rim faster.
data.author: Thomas Bicycle

data.text: Sounds like you may have pads designed for ceramic coated rims but your rims aren‚Äôt coated. I have about the same mileage on a set of Andra coated rims‚Äîthey are still indistinguishable from new, showing no brake pad wear at all.
data.author: M Sebastian Richard Williams

data.text: Those hubs are a great mix between reliable and low cost. They should work very well. Re the Andra 30 rims....in 26 inch and unless you are really heavy, you can probably get by with 32 spoke rather than 36. I've had a set on one of my bikes in 32--in ten years of use they have never so much as gone slightly out of true, no need for spoke re-tensioning, etc. I think the majority of expedition bikes that come with those rims in 26 inch are supplied with 32 spokes. The rims are truly bombproof.
data.author: M Sebastian Richard Williams

data.text: only if they're built well. it seems the market is really moving toward 32-hole, so many options, and so few in 36h and 40h. i guess they figure less spokes means people will break and buy more wheels... that said, it's so much more important to hire a good wheel builder when you're stuck using 32-hole, and you obviously had the good fortune of one being at your disposal. triple-butted spokes, and brass nipples are a must
data.author: Brent Joly

data.text: I have the exact same thing. No problem after thousands of kms.
data.author: Thomas Bicycle

data.text: My Deore rear hub failed after 1000kms. Somehow the freehub thread stripped inside the hub. Had to get a rebuild mid tour.
data.author: Ross Gilbertson

data.text: Shimano hubs are very good, 36 spokes my choice, double wall rims of a good brand will help too.
data.author: John Terranova

data.text: I would go with XT hubs if they come in 36 holes. i have XT for touring and the seals are top, not sure about deore which i have for commuting. (36 and 40 holes are usually for tandems. i had 32 holes XT on a touring tandem loaded and did 3,000 km with not problem.) The Andra should be fine on 32 holes as the holes are directed to specific side of the hub (16 to the left, 16 to the right). regular rims have the holes directed vertical and the nipples are in stress always since new. Spokes mounted on Andra Rims are not twisted at the nipple, then stronger.
data.author: Jo En Pausa

data.text: I've been using deore LX hubs from 1992, still going strong after 20years and over 50 thousand kilometres
data.author: √ñzkal √ñzsoy

data.text: the best of the best shimano is XT 756 ( made in malaysia ) undestructible
data.author: St√©phane sint√®s

data.text:
I have that rim and I'm using a dynamo hub front. For rear I have Shimano XT FH-M756A, This post is a little out of date but it seems the general advice is that Shimano is pretty reliable. http://travellingtwo.com/resources/which-hubs-to-use-for-bike-touring
Which Hubs To Use For Bike Touring
travellingtwo.com
data.author: Scott Diamond

data.text: Great rims and good choice. I did wear a rear one out but was due to a heavy bike and a lot of weight but won't hold that against them. Couple things to bare in mind. I would choose 36 hole mainly because if either the rim fails or the hub fails its easier to get a 36 hole replacement then a 32. Also have you considered a rohloff? The wheels are symmetrical with same Spoke lengths so not only stronger but very easy to build replacement
data.author: Tim Bridgman

data.text:
I bought exact hub, and when open the box and spin it I had impression it's not going very smoothly but thought it just need to brake in or something, but read some comments on bike24.com and all 3 comments were saying it's not lubricated well, so open it and in fact there was very little to none grees on 1 side so when greased it's perfect. I think its decent hub for its price, you should go with it with no worries, it's easy to service.
BIKE24 Online Shop | Everything for your bike
bike24.com
data.author: Karol Adamski

data.text:
I absolutely swear by the dt swiss 545, very robust and reliable, it's also suited for ebikes, because it is very robust. driven them for thousands of kilometers, never had a problem, I trust these! they also make excellent hubs for the rear! I drive a rohloff in the back and a SON dynamo on the front. https://nabendynamo.de/en/products/hub-dynamos/for-standard-forks/ https://www.dtswiss.com/en/components/rims-mtb/trekking/545-d
for Standard Forks ‚Äì SON Hub Dynamos
nabendynamo.de
data.author: Franky Racoon Tyrell

data.text: Undoubtedly the best hubs you can get for international touring. üëåüèΩ Shimano hubs are serviceable anywhere in the world... their parts are easily available. I made the mistake of using some extremely expensive hubs and the hubs broke 3 times on me. I was delayed 3 months waiting for replacement parts in a country and then the hub broke again. I replaced my expensive hubs with these Shimano Deore XT and didn't have any problems at all.
